Money that he has from selling dairy products just enough for food, so to expand his business he needs more funds. For the purpose of expanding his business he applied for 1200 USD to purchase one more milk cow for the estimated price of 700 USD, and for two calves, each for 250 USD.

loans.use: Going to purchase one cow and two calves

loans.name: Ekubchon

texts.ru:
Ekubchon H. is a member of the group "Ekubchon". He has been receiving loans from Microinvest for more the two years. Ekubchon works for "Binokor" as a construction worker and earns a salary of 70 dollars a months. He is married and his wife is not employed. Mr. H. used his first loan to buy a calf and after fattening it for 5 months sold it with profit. He used his income and an additional loan to buy a cow and two calves. His wife helps him in his business. With the new loan Mr. H. is planning to buy two calves for fattening and sale. He is planning to use the profits to buy additional animals and the rest will be spent to support his family. Mr. H. is hoping to repay the loan within the next eight months.

Translated from Russian by Anya Lyuksyutova, Kiva volunteer.

Хакназаров Екубчон член группы «Екубчон». Кредитуется в «Микроинвест» более 2-х лет. Екубчон работает в ООО «Бинокор» строителем и получает 70$ в месяц заработную плату. Женат. Жена не работает (домохозяйка). Клиент на первый полученный кредит купил бычка и после откорма в течении 5 месяцев продал с прибылью. На полученный доход и новый кредит он купил одну корову и 2-х телят. . Ему в этом помогает жена. На полученный кредит клиент планирует приобрести 2-х голов крупного рогатого скота для их откормки и перепродажи. Вырученные деньги он будет использовать на приобретение молодняка, а оставшуюся прибыль будет направлять на содержание своей семьи. Клиент планирует выплатить кредит в течение 8 месяцев.

loans.use: Purchase of livestock

loans.name: Abel

texts.en:
Abel A. is married with a two month old daughter. He is a vendor who has a store connected to his house in which his wife runs the front counter. He first entered the line of business with his father. Over the years he saved and soon had enough to open his own business.

He hopes to have more children in the near future, but wants to be sure he will have enough money to raise them well. He needs to increase his business and keep it stocked at all times. For this reason he asks for a loan which will allow him to buy various goods like men and women, makeup, jewelry, etc.

loans.use: To buy spices, hair dye, grocery bags, under garments for men and women, light bulbs, makeup, women’s jewelry.

loans.name: Ni Kadek Ayu Ardani

texts.id:
Kadek Ayu Ardani has two children. Her first kid is 15 year old and he is in junior high school. Her 2nd kid is 9 year old and he is in Primary school.

She bought 2 female breeding pigs for IDR 2 million (around USD 220). She farms them in traditional ways. She doesn't keep her pigs in a hut as she doesn't have money to build one. She plans to build a pig hut once she succeed in selling the piglets produced by her breeding pigs.

One of her pig is now pregnant. The other one has just delivered 8 piglets recently. When these piglets are 2 month old, she will be able to sell them for IDR 200 thousand/ piglet (around USD 22), so in total she can earn a revenue of USD 175 from the selling of 8 piglets. She hopes the pregnant pig can deliver safely.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva Volunteer.

Kadek Ayu Ardani memiliki 2 orang anak. Anak yang pertama berumur 15 tahun duduk dibangku SMP. Anaknya yang kedua berumur 9 tahun duduk dibangku SD. Kadek Ayu Ardani memiliki 2 induk babi lokal yang sudah siap dikawinkan. 2 induk babi ini dibeli dengan harga Rp. 2.000.000.- Ayu Ardani memberi makan masih secara tradisional yaitu dengan memberi daun talas yang sudah direbus lalu dicampurkan dengan dedak padi. Cara pemeliharaannya juga masih secara tradisional, karena belum ada dana tambahan untuk membuat kandang. Rencananya kalau induknya berhasil, Ayu Ardani akan membuat kandang yang permanen. 2 induknya sekarang sudah hamil dan yang satu sudah melahirkan 8 ekor anak babi. Ayu Ardani sangat telaten dalam mengurus induk dan anaknya. Umur 2 bulan anaknya dijual dengan harga 1 ekor babi Rp. 200.000.- jadi total semuanya Rp.1.600.000.- Harapan Ayu Ardani, 1 induknya lagi bisa melahirkan dengan selamat.

loans.use: To buy breeding pig/ female breeder  (Membeli induk babi)

loans.name: Chamroen

texts.en: Mrs. Chamroen R. is a 29-year-old farmer who earns $2.50 per day. Her husband, Mr. Kan Choeurn, earns $3 per day farming and fishing. They live with their only child in Dang Korb Village, Kandal Province. R. requests a $500 loan to purchase a pumping machine to irrigate crops. She hope this loan will improve her family’s financial stability.

loans.use: To purchase a pumping machine to irrigate crops

loans.name: Maquely

texts.es:
Mrs Maquely A. is a very hard-working lady. Since 6 years, she runs a grocery store from her home where she sells various products like food. She is a single mother with four children and she tries to provide them with everything they need.

Now, she urgently needs to purchase goods in order to commercialise them. However, she does not have the economic resources to buy them herself. That is why she requests a loan from CEPRODEL. The loan will benefit her and her household as she will be able to take care of her four children.

Translated from Spanish by Jimena Almendares Leistner, Kiva Volunteer.

La dama Maquely A. es una dama muy esforzada el cual desde hace seis años se ha dedicado al negocio de la venta de productos varios tanto personales como comestibles en su propia casa de habitación donde posee una pulpería propia a la que abastece con sus productos. Es una madre soltera y con cuatro hijos a los que debe de mantener y proporcionar todas las condiciones necesarias para subsistir.

La necesidad que esta dama atraviesa es la urgencia de adquirir sus productos para comercializarlos por el hecho de que no cuenta con el recurso económico que le permita llevar a cabo esta labor. Para ello acude a Ceprodel para ser beneficiada con el crédito oportuno para la compra de los productos. Con este crédito será beneficiada ella y su humilde casa de habitación donde alberga a sus cuatro hijos.

loans.use: Grocery store

loans.name: Madeleine

texts.fr:
Born in 1972 in SAKETE (in PLATEAU County) in the Southeast of BENIN, Ms. Madeleine O. is married and the mother of four. She sells sardines, canned tomatoes, and vegetable oil (from palm kernels or peanuts), cookies, and various other food items. She discovered a commercial zone in her village where she goes every weekend to display her different goods. She would also like to establish a sales outlet in Cotonou, her place of residence. And so she is applying for this loan to realize her noble ambition.

Translated from French by Daniel Kuey, Kiva volunteer

Née en 1972 à SAKETE dans le département du PLATEAU au Sud-est du BENIN, dame O. Madeleine est mariée et mère de 4 enfants. Elle vend des sardines, des tomates en boîtes, de l’huile végétale (de palmiste ou d’arachide), des biscuits et autres divers produits vivriers. Elle a découvert une zone commerciale dans son village où elle va tous les weekends pour exposer ses différents produits. Elle voudrait également installer un point de vente à Cotonou son lieu de résidence. Elle sollicite donc ce prêt pour réaliser sa noble ambition.

loans.use: To buy 30 boxes of sardines and 25 boxes of canned tomatoes

loans.name: Olga Cristina

texts.es:
Olga is 41 years old, married, and has two sons, who are 11 and 14 years old. They live in the Laureles Norte neighbourhood of the city.

Olga and her husband both work to support their family. He is a bricklayer and she has been running a small general store from a room in their house for the last eight years, which she started using the money she had saved. Her business shows steady growth and she hopes that by working hard she will be able to grow it further.

Her current plan, however, is to secure her home and shop by building a wall for the front room, where the shop is located.

Translated from Spanish by MuseAndThinker, Kiva Volunteer

Doña Olga habita en el barrio Laureles Norte en donde tiene una pulpería en su casa de habitación, tiene 41 años de edad, es casada y tiene dos hijos de 11 y 14 años de edad, su esposo trabaja como albañil y ambos aportan para el sustento del hogar. Doña Olga tiene 8 años de tener esta pulpería, y durante todos estos años ha podido crecer mucho, ya que cuando empezó no vendía lo que vende actualmente. Esta pequeña pulpería la pudo montar gracias a unos ahorros que ella tenía. Y planea seguir trabajando duramente para que el negocio pueda salir adelante y crecer económicamente. Pero por el momento sus planes son darle seguridad a su casa y al negocio, necesita construir un muro frontal para su casa de habitación.

loans.use: Building of a wall in front of her house and shop

loans.name: Jean

texts.fr:
Jean A. is a 42 year old married father of 3 children, 2 of whom are in apprenticeship and 1 who is in school. He works in the field of lumber and has owned, for a short time, his small timber business in Assahoun, a village located approximately 50 kilometers from Lomé, the capital of Togo. Jean is a faithful client of FECECAV and is requesting his second loan to purchase more timber for resale in order to earn more profits and care for the needs of his family.

Translated from French by Allana Carlyle, Kiva Volunteer

Jean A. est âgé de 42 ans, marié et père de 3 enfants dont 2 sont en apprentissage et 1 à l’école. Il est dans le bois et tient son petit commerce de planches depuis quelques temps à Assahoun, un village situé à environ 50 kilomètres de Lomé, la capitale togolaise. Jean est un client fidèle de FECECAV car il est à son deuxième crédit et souhaite par ce dernier acheter plus de planches pour la revente afin de dégager plus de profits et subvenir aux besoins de sa famille.

loans.use: To purchase timber for resale

loans.name: Sada's Tujitahid Group

texts.en:
Sada is married with one child who is three years old. She runs a small food shop. Every day, she works from 7:00 A.M. to 9:00 P.M. at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

Sada now hopes for a loan to buy more food items such as sugar, salt, juice, rice, and maize flour for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members who also have businesses dealing with food vending, fish sales, firewood and charcoal sales, and salon ownership.

loans.use: To buy more food items to increase her stock

loans.name: Mrs. Sok Sovannara Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The Village Bank, consisting of nine people living in Preak Ta Aek Village in Kandal Province, is led by 38-year-old Village Bank President Mrs. S. S., the mother of three children who are all attending the local school. She is a mat maker who can make $6 per day, and since her business is doing well, she is requesting a loan to buy more raw materials to make more mats in order to meet customer demand. Her husband, Mr. Duong Kea, is a motorbike taxi driver who can make $3 per day, a small income that nonetheless contributes to the family’s support.

This is a village bank loan consisting mainly of end-of-term loans. Two members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. Theses members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor, allowing them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy more raw materials to make more mats in order to meet customer demand.

loans.name: Rosa

texts.en:
Rosa Q. is an unmarried mother of two, ages 5 and 3. She is a member of FINCA Perú in the community bank, Juanito. Rosa works during the day selling candies while walking up and down the main streets of Ayacucho. Additionally, she cleans bathrooms in the evenings.

With her loan of 1000 soles, she will invest into her candy business. Rosa is currently saving to reach her goals of owning her own larger house and her own store where she can sell candies and groceries.

loans.use: With her loan of 1000 soles, she will invest into her candy business.

loans.name: Naseem Akhtar M.iqbal Group

texts.en:
Naseem Akhtar baji is a 31-year-old, married, extremely active lady. She resides in the city of Borewala in Pakistan, and she is the mother of five children (four boys and one daughter), all of whom are enrolled in a local school in her neighborhood. Naseem baji’s husband name is M., and he is a fruit-seller by profession. More specifically, he buys seasonal fruit from the fruit market at wholesale prices, and later sells such fruit on a cart in his community. Further, he has been selling seasonal fruits for the past 5 years.

Naseem Akhtar baji independently operates a wood-selling business, which she started for the benefit of her children because she wants to provide them with a good education and a good name in their society. Notably, Naseem baji has already successfully repaid one loan from Asasah, a microfinance institution in Pakistan. Now she is applying for another loan to buy more seasonal fruits and seasonal vegetables to expand her husband’s business.

She is joined in her loan group by four other members: Jamila baji seeks a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop; Hanifan baji requests a loan to buy cosmetics for her cosmetics sales business; Kalsoom baji is in need of a loan to buy electric supplies (e.g., wires and switchboards) for her electric appliance shop; and Shakooran baji would like a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local, three-wheeled motor vehicle). This is a group loan; as such, the loan proceeds will be distributed amongst the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. Importantly, the group members mutually guarantee one another's loans; as a result, if one group member does not repay her portion of the loan, then the other members are responsible for curing the arrears.

loans.use: To expand and improve her husband's business by purchasing more seasonal fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Tumpe M.

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 30-year-old Tumpe K. from Kyela. She is married with three children between the ages of six and nine. Tumpe has been running a vitenge (a traditional sarong-like garment for women) and crops business since 2004. She buys vitenge and crops on a wholesale basis and sells them in the market for a profit.

She works at the business 9 to 12 hours per day, 7 days per week. Tumpe currently earns about 100 USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of 400 USD in order to purchase more vitenge and rice in bulk. In the future, she plans to open another business. Tumpe thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA: SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit through micro-leasing in Tanzania. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women and uses the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more vitenge and rice in bulk

loans.name: Oscar

texts.es: Oscar tiene 47 años de edad, de estado civil es soltero, vive solo en su casa propia. Se dedica a brindar servicios de mecánica para motos en un espacio que implementó en su casa, lo viene haciendo desde hace 6 años. A Oscar le gusta dejar muy bien arregladas las motos que repara para que los usuarios confíen en él y lo recomienden con otras personas, e ir incrementado su clientela, además, por encontrarse ubicado en una zona muy transitada obtiene buenas ganancias por su trabajo, aunque que es cansado, pero le trae satisfacciones. Es la primera vez que recurre a MFP para obtener un crédito, y está muy entusiasmado y comprometido con su banco comunal. Con el dinero solicitado quiere comprar herramientas para implementar mejor su taller.
texts.en:
Oscar is 47 years old, is unmarried and lives by himself in his own home. He works as a motorcycle mechanic from a workshop he installed at his house, and he has been doing this for the past 6 years. Oscar enjoys repairing motorcycles, and he is growing his client base as his customers trust him and recommend him to others. Additionally he earns a good living from his work as he is located in an area where many people pass by, and although his job is tiring it also rewarding. This is the first time that Oscar has turned to MFP for a loan. He is very excited and committed to his community bank. He will use the loan to buy tools to better equip his workshop.

Translated from Spanish by Sally Bolton, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase tools for his workshop

loans.name: Ran

texts.en: Mr. Ran H. was born in 1947 and he now lives in Neang Toeut village in Kampong Cham province. He and his wife, Mrs. Bun Keat, are farmers who own a plot of land where they cultivate both rice and vegetables. On this plantation, they face a problem because they do not have enough money to hire laborers to work on the field. Thus, Mr. Ran H. decided to request for a loan for this purpose. He has three children, two of whom are farmers who help their parents work and the other is a nurse in the local village. His wife is presented on the right.

loans.use: To hire laborers to work on the field.

loans.name: Safi Nia Group

texts.en:
Wanu has been a firewood seller in the Melinne neighborhood of Zanzibar for 5 years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $35. Every day she works at her business from 8 a.m. to 10 p.m. She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more firewood for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Wanu is 45 years old, divorced, and has three children: ages 24, 23 and 19. She also cares for three additional dependants. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Saumu and Simpe. Each woman also has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more firewood for her business.

loans.name: Mouhamad

texts.en: Mouhamad is a 45-year-old man who lives in Nabatieh, Southern Lebanon with his wife. Mouhamad has been working in agriculture for ten years. He plants different type of vegetables. He requested a loan of $1,000 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase tools for his work. This is the first time that Mouhamad has requested a loan.

loans.use: To purchase tools for his work.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is 35 years old and lives in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon. He has owned a bakery for nine years, and went into this line of business as his father was a baker. Joseph makes 'saj' and 'mankoucheh' at the bakery. The saj bread is baked in a traditional Lebanese cooking dome/metal oven called a 'saj'. Mankoucheh looks like a folded pizza, and its most common toppings are zaatar (thyme), jebneh (cheese) and lahm bi ajin (minced meat). You can eat mankoucheh at any time of the day, but somehow it tastes better in the morning. Joseph is successful in his work because he is a good baker and is known for his excellent mankoucheh. His customers are his friends, neighbors and local people.

Joseph requested a loan of $2000 USD from Kiva partner, Al Majmoua, in order to purchase merchandise for his bakery. This is his third loan cycle and he has always paid on time. In the future, he plans on expanding his bakery.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for his bakery

loans.name: Idrisu

texts.en: Idrisu H. is married with 4 children and received an education through elementary school. Idrisu is a trader who sells sauce pans and charcoal at Kissi near Elmina, which she has done since 1999. While Idrisu is working at her trade, her husband is employed at Komenda college. Idrisu uses her income to pay for her family’s expenses such as school fees and bills. Idrisu will use the loan to purchase additional goods such as sauce pans and charcoal for resale and plans to use her newly gained profits to build a house for her family.

loans.use: To purchase additional goods such as sauce pans and charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a 40-year-old man who lives in the Bekaa with his wife and their two children. Ali has been working as a blacksmith for nine years. Ali requested a loan of $800 US dollars from A. Majmoua in order to purchase a car for his work. This is the first time that Ali has requested a loan.

Ali is speciA. in his work because he does it well. His clients are his friends and neighbors. When he first started his business, he didn’t have a lot of cash. In the future, he plans on expanding his business.

loans.use: Ali will use the loan to purchase a car for his work.

loans.name: Lusaka Upper A Bakyanibera Grace Group

texts.en:
Grace B., age 44, is the group leader of this loan group. She is the single mother of four children, three of whom are going to school. She has been in the business of selling clothes for over seven years.

She has requested a loan to purchase used clothes such as jackets, raincoats, children's clothes, and shoes for sale. She is a hardworking woman whose dream is to educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase used clothes for sale

loans.name: Lysbel Lida

texts.en:
Lysbel is a member of Banco Comunal Sumaqcha, which means Beautiful in Quechua.

Lysbel is single, 23 years old, and lives with her parents. She studies accounting and she sells cosmetics from catalogs, products that she offers her friends and acquaintances, and which she sells primarily on credit. She is planning to start a new business in selling clothing by request.

Lysbel needs a loan of 1,000 soles which she will use to buy clothing and makeup. Her dreams are to finish her current career and have her own stable business and office.

loans.use: To buy clothing and makeup

loans.name: Benkadi (L’Entente) Group

texts.fr:
Les cinq femmes du groupe Benkadi de l’association Dembagnouma  sont toutes mariées. Elles ont une moyenne d’âge de 36 ans et 5 enfants vivant dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies au premier quartier de la ville de Koutiala (région de Sikasso, république du Mali). Elles se sont  connues   à travers des liens   de voisinage et de parenté.
Elles exercent presque la même activité la  vente  de condiments alimentaires  et la restauration. Elles sont très sollicitées dans ces activités. 
Afin  de satisfaire  le besoin de sa clientèle qui ne cesse d’augmenter, le groupe Benkadi  a décidé d’intégrer à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il est à son troisième  prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe). Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Elles  comptent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter, toutes sortes de condiments alimentaires, du riz et du haricot pour la restauration. Les condiments sont vendus en détail et au comptant  au marché de Koutiala et à la maison. Quant aux nourritures elles sont vendues la nuit devant la porte de leur maison. 
 Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen  de 110 000 FCFA au cours de ce cycle qui sera utilisé pour payer les intérêts du prêt, subvenir au besoin de la famille élargie et investir le reste dans les activités. 
Elles ont pour ambition de diversifier leurs activités commerciales.
texts.en:
The 5 women of this “Benkadi” group, part of the Dembagnouma Association, are all married. They have an average age of 36, on average 5 children, and live in big extended traditional families in the first neighborhood of the town of Koutiala (Sikasso region, Republic of Mali). They met because of being from the same neighborhood and being related.

They have almost the same business, selling condiments and cooked food. They are much in demand in these areas. So as to satisfy the needs of their growing clientele, this Benkadi group decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with whom they are on their 3rd solidarity loan (group loan). Both the preceding loans were correctly reimbursed.

They intend to use this loan to buy all sorts of condiments, and rice and dried beans for cooked food. The condiments are sold retail and for cash in the market of Koutiala and out of their homes. As for the food, it is sold in the evening outside the doors of their houses.

They each expect to make an average profit of 110,000 F CFA over the course of this loan cycle. That money will be used to pay the interest on the loan and cover some needs of their extended families, investing any remainder back into their businesses. Their ambition is to diversify their commercial activities.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buying condiments and ingredients for cooked food service

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy E.'s dream is to greatly expand her farm. She is 43 years old and has three children. The income that her family receives from farming helps to pay school tuition, books and school projects for her children. It has also helped her family pay their personal family expenses.

Mercy is now requesting a loan from Community Economic Ventures Inc. worth Php 10,000 in order to purchase complete fertilizers and rice seeds.

CEVI helps small business grow. Like her, other CEVI clients received loans, trainings and insurance coverage.

loans.use: To buy complete fertilizers and rice seeds

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en: Mohamad is a 26-year-old married man with one child. He has been working in the sanitary sector for the past 8 years. In 2006, he decided to open his own business to improve life conditions for his family. Today, Mohamad is requesting to borrow money to buy merchandise to increase his work income.

loans.use: to buy merchandise

loans.name: Venerando

texts.en:
Venerando M. is from the village of Salay Misamis Oriental. He is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Venerando owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail business. The main source of income for his business comes primarily from selling a variety of fruits like "marang" in the local community. Venerando has been engaged in his business for over 2 years and earns approximately 12,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Venerando joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Venerando is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used as additional business capital. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Venerando from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from his business to improve/expand it.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Use as additional business capital

loans.name: Julie

texts.en:
Julie is engaged in food snack vending business in their rural village of Oscariz Ramon, Isabela. She loves vending same through here where she is generating income for her family. She wanted to borrow loan from Kiva lenders of around PHP4, 000 that will be utilize as additional business capital. She hopes to further improve the business so that someday, her family will also be lifted up from poverty. 

Julie is already married to Reynaldo V. Sr. They are blessed with three children, one of them is already married. Her two younger children who were left are still studying; Reynaldo V. Jr. - 16 years old is a high school student and Rizza Joy - 10 years old is in the elementary level of education. Through her business, she hopes to give them her full financial support as they pursue their studies until college.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Mich's Group

texts.en:
This small loan is being requested by three borrowers. Mr. S., 29, has been selected to be a leader by the group member. S. currently teaches the local student for a public school in the village. As another source of family income is from his wife’s decorating business. She is also hired by people to decorate and make up their house when they have a wedding party. S. is skill in teaching to his student through computer system, but he doesn’t own his computer for using purposes, so that he would like a Kiva loan to buy a used computer to support his teaching. The other two borrowers are:
S., 34, is a grocery seller, who asking for a loan to increase to essential items to sell.
S. will be using her loan to purchase rice seeds and fertilizer to grow.

loans.use: To buy a used computer to support his teaching

loans.name: Cherry

texts.en: Cherry D. is from the village of Maanas, Gingoog City. She is 49 years old, is married, and has four school-aged children. Cherry owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Cherry joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase new items to expand her product offering. Cherry is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her 3rd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Aisha's Group

texts.en:
M. Aisha is the leader of her lending group in Ganyana. The group is located on the Busabala landing site near Lake Victoria. Aisha is a hard-working and devoted lady. She has been a farmer and fishmonger in Ganyana for such a long time. Ever since she joined her lending group, life has been a bit more fair and she has been able to educate her children and acquire household items for her family's development. 

Aisha grows bananas, cassava, and sweet potatoes on her farm. She also fishes, and she sells fresh and dried fish to her customers at the landing site. She needs a loan to buy more fish to resell, and to employ laborers on her farm to increase her productivity.

loans.use: To buy fish to resell and to hire laborers for her farm

loans.name: Antonia

texts.en: At the age of 48, Antonia manages a transportation business. Her weekly net income is 600 PHP. She was also engaged in a vending business for almost 20 years, but unfortunately she wasn't able to pursue that business—that's why she switched to motorcycle transport. She desires to avail of a loan from Kiva lenders amounting to 5,000 PHP, to be used for the repair and maintenance of her motorcycle. She is married to Cifriano, a driver. Their marriage was blessed with two children. They are Cherry, 21 years old, and Xavier, 20 years old, both high-school graduates. Their family resides in the village of Del Pilar, Cabatuan, one of the towns in Isabela Province. Their house is near an elementary school.

loans.use: For repair and maintenance of her motorcycle

loans.name: Francis Lemein

texts.en: Francis K. is 26 years old. He is a married father of one school-going child. Francis has been practicing farming on his farm for the last seven years. His farm is in a very productive area within Narok. His customers buy his farm produce in wholesale and they normally come from the Capital city, Nairobi. Francis learned about KADET through an awareness done by KADET staff in his area. This will be his second loan which he is planning to use to buy a new species of potato called “sangi” which research has proven can do very well in this area and have better yield. He hopes to use the profit from this loan to acquire more land for farming to meet the demand for his farm produce. Francis’s future hope and dream is to become a large-scale farmer and have his own farm machinery. He believes he is young and quite energetic thus he can do more if supported financially. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy a new potato species called "sangi"

loans.name: Norah K.

texts.en:
Norah K. M. is married and has four children ranging from the age of ten to twenty-two. Ror the last six years, Norah has run the Baby Face Mini general shop, where she sells vegetables, fruits, snacks and soft drinks to frequent and walk-in customers. Her business is located in Keroka Mali Mali, a semi-urban town. 

Norah's business challenge is the fluctuating demand. She will be using the proceeds of her 20,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) loan to increase her stock of sugar, rice, and cooking fat. In addition to that business, she sells used and new clothes. Her dream in life is to become a wholesaler. She describes herself as hardworking and industrious.

loans.use: To buy 2 bags of sugar, 3 bags of rice, and 1 dozen containers of cooking fat.

loans.name: Amy

texts.fr: Madame Amy D. âgée de 64 ans est vendeuse de légumes dans sa localité à Bambey. C’est une activité qu’elle a embrassée par passion depuis 20 ans. Elle est mère d’enfants âgés et c’est  toujours l’amour du commerce qui la motive sur les affaires. Elle sollicite,ainsi, un crédit de 100 000 frs CFA pour acheter des légumes verts comme les navets, les carottes, les aubergines et du piment. Elle compte avec ce crédit  relancer son activité et mieux satisfaire sa  charmante clientèle.
texts.en:
Mrs. Amy D., aged 64, is a vegetable seller in her village of Bambey. She started this business with a great passion 20 years ago and her love for her business is still motivating her. She is the mother of grown-up children. She applies for a loan of 100,000 CFA francs to buy fresh vegetables, such as turnips, carrots, eggplant and pepper. This loan will hopefully enable Amy to stimulate her business and better serve her charming clientele.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy vegetables

loans.name: Hassan

texts.en:
Hassan is a 56-year-old man who lives in Tyre, Southern Lebanon, with his wife and their five children. Hassan has been working as a car repairman and painter since 1977. He also sells spare auto parts and he changes oil. When Hassan doesn’t work in his garage, he also works as a taxi driver; he is an active man who does his best to improve his family’s financial situation by offering them the best he can. He requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase tools for his garage which will allow him to improve his work. This is the first time that Hassan has requested a loan.

His clients are his friends and neighbors. When Hassan first started his work, he didn’t face difficulties, since he had a good reputation from his previous work as an employee. He decided on this business because of his experience as a car mechanic. In the future, he plans on improving his work.

loans.use: To purchase tools for his garage

loans.name: Priscila

texts.en:
Priscila A. R. lives with her family in La Suiza de Turrialba, a quiet and tranquil region near Costa Rica’s central valley. Priscila is 25 years old and is currently in her 3rd year at “The University for Distance Education” (UNED) studying to become a preschool teacher.

A goal of Priscila’s is to be able to contribute to her family’s income in a significant way, as does her brother. Priscila aspires to open her own business selling clothes in an effort to gain financial independence and to finance her university costs (books, tuition, transportation, etc.). Priscila has developed her sales experience by assisting a colleague with her business.

This will be Priscila’s first loan with Fundacion Mujer. This loan will be used to make initial investments in clothing products to be sold in her community and at university. She will purchase clothes from a store in nearby Cartago (an hour from Turrialba) to sell in La Suiza. Priscila is confident in her estimation of potential earnings to be sought via sales to neighbors, friends and acquaintances.

As a full-time student, most of Priscila’s day is spent in classes; however, she plans to dedicate at least three hours after class every day to her business. Priscila says that for business advice, she consults her mother or sister.

Priscila has been studying part-time to become a preschool teacher since 2003. For financial reasons, she wasn’t able to afford enrollment in a full-time schedule. Recently she has been granted a scholarship with UNED which she will use to enroll in full-time studies. Every fifteen days she must travel to Turrialba (thirty minutes by bus) to attend university - the rest of her classes she takes on the Internet. Part of her motivation to become a teacher stems from the fact that she has always liked caring for children.

Priscila is a hardworking, determined and competent woman. With limited time, she skillfully balances her schedule: Tuesdays and Thursdays she spends working at a local day care; the rest of her time is divided between studying and babysitting her 8-year-old niece. Priscila also loves to play volleyball; she used to have more time to devote to her sport on a competitive team but recently it has become more of a hobby. She likes to spend weekends with her family.

loans.use: To start a business selling clothing

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna M. is from the village of Malaubang Ozamiz city. She is 50 years old. Myrna is widowed and has 3 school-aged children.

To make a living, Myrna sells seafood products including fish and shrimp to the local community. Myrna has been engaged in her business for over 25 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Myrna joined GDMPC to improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Myrna is requesting her first loan from GDMPC, for 10000 PHP, which she will use to purchase additional products to sell.

She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

About GDMPC

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

Note

To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice is a 23-year-old single lady who is a tailor by profession. She opened her tailoring shop in Olkalou eight months ago and thus far, business has been good.

Beatrice was introduced to KADET by her friend and this will be her first loan. She plans to expand by buying new fabric for making new clothes for sale but on order.
 
She plans to grow her business and to diversify to be a distributor of fabric in Olkalou town, a fast-growing town in Kenya.

loans.use: To buy more fabric for her tailoring business

loans.name: Hayde

texts.es:
Hayde, es casado, tiene 48 años y tiene tres hijos, ella es una mujer trabajadora que alterna sus actividades del hogar con la venta de comida en el mercado de San Blas en la Ciudad del Cusco. Su actividad comercial empieza a las 6 a.m. hasta las 4  p.m., ella se levanta muy temprano para ir a su puesto de trabajo donde tiene que alistar los insumos para preparar la comida, ella de lunes a sábados prepara desayuno y almuerzo y los días domingos prepara ceviche. Hayde usará el crédito para comprar víveres como por ejemplo azúcar, fideos, arroz, aceite, etc. La socia es una mujer responsable y por eso sus amigas no dudaron en invitarle a que forme parte del banco comunal “Sacsayhuaman”. Ya son varios años que forma parte del banco comunal “Sacsayhuaman” y le va muy bien. El sueño de la socia es que su hija Verioska se gradué de enfermera y sus demás hijas terminen sus carreras profesionales.       

La socia se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente
texts.en:
Hayde is married, 48 years old, and has three children. She is a hardworking woman who alternates her activities between her home and selling food in the San Blas market of the city of Cuzco. Her business activity begins at 6 a.m. and lasts until 4 p.m.. She gets up very early to go to her workplace where she has to to get the ingredients ready to prepare the food. From Monday through Saturday she prepares breakfast and lunch and on Sundays she prepares ceviche. Hayde will use the loan to buy supplies such as sugar, noodles, rice, oil, etc. This member is a responsible woman and this is why her friends didn't hesitate to invite her to join the communal bank “Sacsayhuaman”. She has been a member of the “Sacsayhuaman” bank for several years now and it is going very well for her. This member's dream is for her daughter Verioska to graduate as a nurse and for her other daughters to finish their professional studies. She is grateful for the opportunity offered in this way and she is committed to making the corresponding payment.

Translated from Spanish by Ellen Donohue, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Hayde will use the loan to purchase supplies such as sugar, noodles, rice, oil, etc.

loans.name: Manuel

texts.en:
Manuel P. is from the village of Brgy. 5, Talakag Bukidnon. He is 58 years old. Manuel is married and has 4 adult-aged children. To make a living, Manuel owns and operates a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing transport services to local community members. Manuel has been a motorella driver for over 15 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Manuel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Manuel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. Manuel is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to expand the services he provides. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Manuel from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of the family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to expand services provided.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy products that are basic necessities

loans.name: Gabrail

texts.en:
Gabrail is a farmer. His farming operation covers different crops like cassava, plantains and okra. When his crops are harvested, he sells some of the farm produce to sellers. He is requesting for a loan of NGN 60,000 to hire laborers to clear his farm   .

Gabrail is 48 years old and married with 4 children. He is very thankful to all Kiva lenders for their financial assistance.

loans.use: To hire laborers to clear his farm

loans.name: Annet

texts.en: Annet is widowed with three children and all her children go to school. She also takes care of her late sister’s children. She owns a mini-bar at home selling beer and local drinks.  She buys crates of beer from delivery vans and local drinks from Mengo Kisenyi. She incurs little transport costs from Mengo Kisenyi to her bar in Kitawuluzi. Annet sells to all categories of people but only mature ones. She wants to use this loan of 700,000/= to buy more crates of beer and jerrycans of local drinks and gin.  Besides this beer business, she is also a food vendor in the area. She has been doing this bar business for five years. She works seven days a week.  Her business challenges include defaulters and thieves. She aspires to see her business grow big and own a fully stocked bar. She joined MCDT to acquire more capital for her business. The family has no access to electricity or piped water.

loans.use: To buy more crates of beer and jerry cans of local gin

loans.name: Milagros

texts.en:
Milagros D. C., 57, is from the village of Awallan, Baggao, Cagayan. She is married and has one adult-aged child. To make a living, Milagros owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Milagros has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 3,200 PHP when she sells her raised pig.

In 2006, Milagros joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Milagros has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from ASKI. Milagros is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be the eighth loan taken out by Milagros from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Candelaria

texts.en:
Candelaria R. is from the village of Tagulalo, Aurora Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 68 and married with 11 adult children. To make a living, Candelaria owns a retail store selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste. Candelaria has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month.

In 2007, Candelaria joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Candelaria has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from GDMPC which was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Candelaria is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the third loan taken out by Candelaria from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy additional used clothing.

loans.name: Rosa Maria's Group

texts.es: Las señoras que participan en este grupo soy mujeres emprendedoras ya que cada uno tuvo la creatividad de iniciar su propio negocio; se dedican a la venta de medicina lo cual le ha ayudado a sacar adelante a la familia, una de ellas tiene una venta de juguetes y venta de ropa usada, en lo cual le va muy bien y también una de ellas se dedica a la pintura, pinta paisajes y esto le ha ayudado a salir adelante y ayudar a su esposo con los gastos de la casa. el deseo de las tres es sobre salir y ser mujeres de exito
texts.en:
The women in this group are very enterprising women since each one has the creativity needed to start her own business. One of them make a living selling medicines, which has helped her make headway for her families. One of the women sells toys and used clothing, which has gone very well. Another makes a living in art, painting landscapes, and this has helped her and her husband cover household expenses. All three wish to keep making headway and become successful women.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Invest in their businesses

loans.name: Karanja Ole

texts.en:
Karanja Ole S. is 41 years old. He is married to Sempeta S. and he is the father of two children. Karanja is a farmer and he has been doing the farming on his own piece of land for the last 10 years.

He learned about KADET from marketing awareness done by KADET staff in his area. This will be his first loan. He is planning to spend the 50,000 shillings to prepare his land for planting wheat, which has proved to be doing very well due to favorable climatic conditions. With the profits he hopes to make from the proceeds of this loan, he plans to plow more land for farming to increase his wheat production. 

His future dream is that he will become a large-scale wheat farmer in his area. He is a hardworking man who is determined to achieve his set goals.

loans.use: He is planning to spend 50,000 shillings to prepare land for planting wheat

loans.name: Maame

texts.en:
Maame A. sells provisions at Takoradi. She has received junior high education. She is divorced but responsibly makes sure that her two children are properly taken care of.

Maame’s loan will be used to buy extra provisions to sell. She anticipates ploughing back her profit into her business.

loans.use: To buy extra provisions to sell

loans.name: Esi Ayibe

texts.en: Esi Ayibe A. is married to a teacher and has a child. She has received senior high education.  Esi prepares fante kenkey to sell at Elmina. Esi uses her income to help her husband provide the basic needs of the family. Esi will use the loan to purchase more maize to prepare kenkey to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Esi plans to save towards her child’s education.

loans.use: To purchase more maize to prepare kenkey to sell

loans.name: Tania Margoth

texts.es:
Tania es conviviente, tiene 34 años y 2 hijos, Tania junto a su esposo tienen un taller mecánica en un local alquilado, además Tania tiene una tienda de repuestos en un local alquilado, además Tania vende ropa a pedido.
Tania es socia del Banco Comunal Qory Qaytu que significa Hilo de Oro en quechua y solicita un crédito de 1750 para la compra de chompas, pantalones.
El sueño de Tania son tener una tienda de ropa.
texts.en:
Tania is 34 years old, in a common law marriage, and has two children. She and her husband manage an auto repair shop from a rented location. In addition, Tania also sells spare parts at their store. She also sells clothing upon request.

Tania is a member of the Communal Bank “Qory Qaytu”, which means “Thread of Gold” in Quechua. She is requesting a loan of 1750 PEN in order to buy sweaters and trousers. Her dream is to open a clothing store.

loans.use: Purchase sweaters & trousers

loans.name: Pitaya Group

texts.es:
El grupo pitahaya lo conforman tres féminas trabajadoras originarias de Masaya cuidad de la flores y cuna de folklore nicaragüense. La coordinadora del grupo es la señora Antonia M. de 43 años ella se dedica a la crianza de animales de patio como pelibue, vacas, cerdo y gallinas con la ayuda de uno de sus hijos y un nieto. Ella en la actualidad con el préstamo piensa invertir en sandalias para diversificar su negocio.

Una de las integrantes es Jeissel B. Carballo de 29 años trabaja desde hace tres años en el comercio de productos Avon marca reconocida por su ventas vía catalogo, ella con el crédito desea mejorar su negocio y cumplir con sus encargos. Mientras  Auxiliadora Mejía hace diez años inicio una pequeña venta en la que en comienzo vendiendo pan, gaseosa y helado actualmente es una pulpería donde distribuye de todo un poco desde granos básicos, carne y cuadernos entre otros productos.
texts.en:
The Pitahaya group is made up of three hardworking women from Masaya, city of flowers and Nicaraguan folklore. The group coordinator is Mrs. Antonia M., who is 43. She raises farm animals such as pelibuey sheep, cows, pigs and chickens with the help of one of her children and a grandson. She is planning on investing the loan in sandals to diversify her business. 

One of the members is Jeissel B. Carballo, 29, who for the last three years has worked selling Avon products. She has been recognized for her catalog sales. She wants to improve her business with the loan and fill her orders. Auxiliadora Mejía has had a small store for ten years where she sells bread, soft drinks, and ice cream. She distributes basic grains, meat, and notebooks, among other products.

loans.use: To purchase sandals

loans.name: Atoussé

texts.fr: atoussé est une femme de 43 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 4 enfants. Elle vit avec sa famille dans le quartier d'attiégou à Lomé. elle a une ancienneté de 4 ans dans son commerce. Sa clientèle se compose de toutes personnes et elle s'approvisionne au marché local d'adawlato. elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour s'approvisionner avec 12 cartons de produits génériques. avec le revenu de son commerce elle contribue aux dépenses de sa famille.
texts.en: Atousse is a 43-year old woman, married and the mother of four. She lives with her family in the Attiégou district in Lomé. She has four years of experience in her business. Her customer base is very diverse, and she stocks up at the local market of Adawlato. She is seeking a loan from WAGES in order to purchase 12 boxes of basic needs products. She uses the revenues from her business to contribute to the family budget.

loans.use: Purchasing basic needs products

loans.name: Mary Ines

texts.es: La Sra. Mary es cliente antigua,  se dedica a la confección y venta  de deportivos, buzos, poleras, chamarras en su tienda,  en esta actividad le colaboran sus dos hijas mientras ella atiende otro puesto que adquirió recientemente en la que comercializa también los deportivos que confecciona.  Doña Mary vive en casa familiar en la zona los andes de la ciudad de la paz. El destino del crédito esta destinada para adquirir Telas para realizar poleras para este fin de año, la Sra. es una cliente muy trabajadora y responsable siempre velando por el bienestar de su familia, esta muy agradecida con la institución por el apoyo brindado.
texts.en: Mrs. Mary is a returning client, she works creating and selling sporting clothes, hoodies, sweaters, jackets at her store, she gets the help of her daughters at this store, while she works at another site that bought recently where she also sells items she creates. Mrs. Mary lives in a family house in the Andes zone in the city of La Paz. She is requesting the loan to buy fabric to saw new sweaters this year. Mrs. Mary is a very hard working and responsible client who is always working for the well being of her family, and is very grateful to the institution for the support received.

loans.use: to buy fabric to create sweaters and other sporting gear for her store

loans.name: Nabeela's Group

texts.en:
Nabeela is the resident of Jaranwala, a small city in Pakistan known for its agricultural industry. She has been living in this city, since her marriage, in a 2 roomed brick house with her family. She is a very active and caring lady. She prefers to stay at home and manage the household responsibilities. She has given birth to 3 daughters. Her elder daughter is studying in kindergarten while the other two are too young to attend school. 

Nabeela's husband is a carpenter by profession and operates a furniture making and sales business. He has a shop in the market from where he displays his hand-made furniture to his clients for selling. He is an expert in his work and each piece of furniture sells for a good price. 

Nabeela has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan, he will buy wood, nails and furniture polisher in larger quantities to make more furniture to display from his shop. This will help him offering more variety of furniture to his clients for selling and to make more income.  

Nabeela is hopeful that an investment will take her husband’s business to a more profitable position and will also expand his business on a larger scale. 
She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 2nd loan application. In the previous loan year, she has proven herself as a very responsible client who has paid her installments on time and she never missed a single meeting. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Nabeela.

loans.use: To buy wood, nails and furniture polish for furniture making & sales business.

loans.name: Warda

texts.en:
Warda is a young woman from Jabalia refugee camp in Gaza Strip. She is a mother of two daughters and two sons. Warda's husband has been a Palestinian NationA. Authority employee since 2005. Warda and her husband, Salama, decided to start a sheep farm, pictured above, since they have a big family. Warda came to FATEN and took a loan to purchase additionA. sheep and animA. feed. Warda and her husband raise animals for sale, which is increasingly rewarding and helps the family live a better life.

Warda's husband appears in the picture because she is conservative, as are most of Gaza's citizens.

About this loan product:
FATEN offers loan products that are designed to serve borrowers all over Palestine, including some religiously conservative areas. A key tenet of Islam is the prohibition of interest in the lending or accepting of money. This prohibition is based on the belief that money should be seen only as a medium of exchange and that it has no value in itself. FATEN has adapted the terms of this loan to fit the culturA. context by attaching a 0% interest rate to the loan. In order to cover its costs, FATEN does charge a servicing fee. The amount you see fundraising includes both the principA. loan and the loan servicing fees. As with all Kiva loans, you should expect to have your funds returned to you in accordance with the repayment schedule attached to this loan. For more information on lending in the Muslim world, please visit Kiva's Muslim World Lending helptext: http://tinyurl.com/3aekx8m

loans.use: To purchase sheep and animal feed

loans.name: Meldante's Group

texts.en:
Meldante B. is from the village of Linglingay, Cauayan City, Isabela. He is 25 years old. Meldante is the group leader of an 8-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Meldante is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Meldante owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Meldante has been engaged in his business for over 1 year and earns approximately 3500 PHP monthly for these activities.

In 2010, Meldante joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Meldante is requesting a loan of 7000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Meldante from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement his income. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Rufo

texts.es: Rufo, de 39 años, vive en compañía de su esposa y sus dos hijos en una casa arrendada; juntos se esfuerzan cada día para salir adelante.Desde hace 4 años, este emprendedor hombre trabaja ofreciendo servicio de transporte con su auto, que es su esencial herramienta de trabajo. Sale todos los días a recorrer las calles de su ciudad en búsqueda de ocasionales clientes que solicitan el servicio de transporte a distintos puntos de su ciudad, además obtiene regulares ganancias pues cobra su servicio de acuerdo a la distancia. Considera que su trabajo es rentable porque el servicio que ofrece es muy solicitado en su ciudad, además siempre trata en lo posible de recorrer zonas urbanas que significa en su negocio prolongar el buen funcionamiento de su movilidad y de esta manera retrasa el desgaste. Para el futuro tiene planeado mejorar y comprar  un carro más para brindarlo en alquiler.Es el  14avo crédito que tiene  con MFP, y  se siente seguro de contar con este apoyo financiero ya que siempre ha demostrado  ser responsable en sus pagos, además  le agrada ser parte de su banco comunal porque  todos sus integrantes son personas responsables y muy solidarias. Esta muy agradecido con todas las  personas que serán gestoras del préstamo pues le será  muy útil en el progreso de su negocio.Rufo tiene planeado invertir el dinero solicitado en la compra de repuestos y el pago de mantenimiento mecánico de su carro, y de esta manera espera salir adelante.
texts.en:
Rufo is 39 years old.  He lives with his wife and two children in a rental house.  Together they work hard every day to get ahead.

For four years, this enterprising man has worked offering transport services in his car which is his essential work tool.  He goes out every day, driving through the city streets in search of occasional customers who require his transport service to get to different parts of the city.  He makes regular profits as he charges for his service according to distance travelled.  Rufo considers his work to be profitable because the service he offers is very much in demand in his city.  He also always tries, whenever possible, to provide his services in urban areas because, in his business, this is a good way to keep his vehicle in good working order and delays wear and tear on the vehicle.  In the future, he plans to improve and buy a further car that he can rent out.

This is Rufo's 14th loan with MFP and he feels secure with this financial support behind him.  He has always shown himself to be responsible with his loan repayments and he likes being a member of his community bank because the members are responsible people who are very supportive of each other.  He is very grateful to the people who will help fund his loan as it will be very useful to him in making progress in his business.

Rufo plans to invest his loan money in buying spare parts and paying for his car to be serviced.  In this way, he hopes to get ahead.

loans.use: To buy spare parts and pay for his car to be serviced

loans.name: Sonya's Group

texts.en:
It’s amazing to see people who find courage to be optimistic when they face many struggles. Some cope with it thanks to the support of close ones, some with the help of personal beliefs, and some by using their faith. 

Sonya B., 54, is a leader of this group. She is one of those people who, in spite of harsh conditions, push forward and look for a bright spot in a seemingly dark future. Sonya and her husband, a construction worker, step by step built their own home and gave birth to four sons and a daughter. Unfortunately, the oldest boy was born with innate physical disabilities, and needs special care and treatment and constant attention. But Sonya was not discouraged by the illness of her son, and she started looking for ways of assisting her husband financially. She chose private entrepreneurship, because it’s the most profitable option for her.

In 2007, Sonya saved some money to purchase a couple of heads of cattle. She had to remember her skills from her youth. Year by year Sonya was blessed with success and achieved some good results in cattle breeding. In three years she managed to increase the size of the cattle stock dramatically. Now the business generates at least 5,000 soms monthly. Sonya applied for a loan in order to purchase additional cattle and keep her stock big and healthy. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase cattle.

loans.name: Chea

texts.en:
The woman shown in the picture is Chea Y., 47, who currently lives in Kompong Tom province. Chea Y. earns a living by raising pigs in a pigpen behind her house. She raises them both for their offspring and for slaughter. In addition, she also cultivates a rice crop, while her husband works as a local fisherman. They have four children, three of whom are single and one is married. 

It is the time for planting the dry-season rice field but she can't grow her crop on her farmland because of insufficient money. In order to deal with this problem, Chea Y. is asking for a Kiva loan to rent a plow to plow her farmland and to buy fertilizers, gasoline, and seeds for planting.

loans.use: To rent a plow to plow her farmland and buy fertilizers, gasoline, and seeds for planting

loans.name: Chourng

texts.en:
Chourng Y., 56, resides with her family in Kampong Chnang province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. Y. and her husband sell traditional drums, earning an income of USD 4 per day. Each month, the family has to spend USD 80 on food and USD 12 on other necessary expenses. 

Y. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase raw materials to produce drums. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: buy raw materials to produce traditional drums

loans.name: Adjoa

texts.en: Adjoa D. lives with her husband and 4 children. She sells firewood at Nkroful, near Takoradi, which she has been doing for five years. Her husband is a farmer.  Adjoa assists her husband with the household expenses by using her income to educate the children.  Adjoa will use the loan to purchase extra quantities of firewood for resale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Adjoa plans to invest in the sale of salt.

loans.use: to purchase extra quantities of firewood for resale.

loans.name: Kuljamal's Group

texts.en:
Kuljamal J. is the treasurer of this group. She is 50 and married to a driver. Together with her husband, she has raised five children: four daughters and a son. Two daughters are married and live separately with their families, the son works in construction, the third daughter is in the sewing workshop and the youngest daughter graduates a school this year. 

Once Kuljamal applied for a loan and she got 10000 soms, in six months, she repaid the loan and earned an additional 30,000 soms. Since that moment, she has cultivated agricultural products. She also sells dairy products and makes about 200 soms daily. With money received from the loan, she wants to purchase fuel for farming. In the future, Kuljamal wants to purchase a truck for her business.

Where Did This Loan Come From? 

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple P bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase fuel

loans.name: Kilonzi

texts.en:
Kilonzi M. is 37 year old, married and has three children. For nine years he has been making furniture. He employs four people in his business. He also operates a dairy to supplement his income.

Kilonzi has requested 80,000 KES to open another furniture workshop. He is very grateful to Faulu Kenya because he previously serviced two loans which he used to build up his business. He hopes to fully establish his furniture business in the future.

loans.use: To open another furniture workshop

loans.name: Shelmith

texts.en: Shelmith is 38 years old, married and a mother of four.  She sells shoes to earn her living.  She has been in this business for four years.  She has learnt how to manage her business by budgeting and saving some money through Faulu Kenya.  She hopes to open a boutique in the future.  She has requested 15,000 Kes to buy shoes.

loans.use: To buy shoes for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to  buy some seed for his land and extend his agriculture business.

loans.name: Jorge Ernesto

texts.es:
Jorge es soltero de 23 años de edad, vive en casa de sus padres, la cual  es propia y cuenta con todos los servicio ( agua, luz y desagüe) en el distrito de Olmos, ubicado a una hora del departamento de Lamabayeque.  Los pobladores de éste distrito se dedican a la agricultura, ganadería y tiene festividades religiosas que forma parte de las costumbres de los pobladores.

Jorge  labora como chofer de su mototaxi (transporte que se utiliza para movilizarse en distancias cortas, con un cupo máximo de 3 personas) desde hace 2 años aproximadamente, está actividad lo realiza en su mismo distrito, apesar de la competencia, el trata en lo posible desde muy temprano movilizar una buena cantidad de pasajeros a sus diferentes destinos, y así tener mayor cantidad de ingresos para solventar sus gastos y necesidades.

El crédito que ha solicitado a Edpyme Alternativa es de 500 nuevos soles y su destino será para el mantenimiento y cambio de algunos repuestos que necesita su mototaxi para poder seguir trabajando y mejorar su calidad de vida.  Jorge es un hombre muy responsable y conocido en Olmos por ser trabajador  y con muchas ganas de salir adelante.
texts.en:
Jorge, 23, is single living in his parents’ house which they own and has all basic utilities (water, electricity and sewage) in Olmos located an hour from Lambayeque Department.  Residents of this district are in farming and livestock raising and have religious festivities that are part of the customs of the residents.

Jorge has worked as a mototaxi driver (transportation used for short distances; can carry a maximum of 3 passengers) for two years approximately.  He carries out this activity in his own district.  Despite competition he does his best, starting very early ,to take a good number of passengers to their various destinations so that he can earn higher income to meet his needs and expenses.

The loan he’s asked Edpyme Alternativa for is in the amount of 500 new soles that he will use to service and replace some parts that the mototaxi needs to continue operating and to improve his quality of life.  Jorge is a very responsible man and known in Olmos for being hard working with a strong desire to get ahead.

loans.use: to service and replace some parts on his mototaxi.

loans.name: Irina's Group

texts.en:
Irina, 40, is the leader of this group. A few years ago she became a widow, but it didn’t keep her from becoming an ideal parent and a role model for her three daughters and a son. Two of her kids still depend on Irina financially and that motivates her to provide a steady income. 

For four years Irina has been breeding cattle. A loan received in 2007 helped her to get involved in this small business. Along with cattle breeding Irina is involved in a home supplies retail outlet in a local market. Thanks to both businesses, Irina receives a profit of 4,000 soms per month. Now the herd has been expanded to three head. Irina plans to continue breeding cattle, therefore she asks Kiva lenders to finance the purchase of one head of cattle. Irina’s big wish and a long-term goal is to build a house of her own. 

         --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase cattle.

loans.name: Gulsunoy

texts.en:
Gulsunoy is married and has a grown daughter. She lives in Khujand, Tajikistan and runs a small business selling children's clothing in several markets. Gulsunoy owns three vending facilities and has been in this trade for six years. Her inventory is characterized by uniqueness and high quality. She tries to choose good quality merchandise which will always be in demand and sell well.

 Gulsunoy is requesting a loan of 7000 Somoni to increase her stock of goods for the summer season. She believes her conscientious efforts and persevering work will help her expand her business even more and boost her sales. Gulsunoy is ready to invest in her family's well-being and is planning to work hard to ensure a stable future for them.  
 
More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History
